text: along the waterways of the Bay of Bengal
conflict and persecution scar Myanmar's
moves towards democracy to reach Chen Yi
pin it's a two-hour journey by boat the
camp is home to 4,000 reinjure Muslims
who fled Buddhist attacks three years
ago on our way we pass a man tending the
grave of his two month old baby boy
seven children have died here in the
last month none of them saw a doctor
this is why two months ago Buddhist mobs
violently attacked international aid
agencies in the state capital sit way
offices were ransacked and those
providing health care to the rich injure
forced to leave that means there are now
tens of thousands of Muslims like Arab
Ana without access to medical help she's
in so much pain she can no longer walk I
want to be treated she says but I'm
scared if I'm taken to hospital the
Buddhists will attack me across camp we
hear similar stories there have been
only three visits from Burmese
government doctors since the aid
agencies left and no one trusts
Buddhists to transfer them safely to
hospital what's happening here isn't
being dictated by the central Burmese
government but by the local Rakhine
buddhist community it's them who are
stopping these Muslim Raheja leaving
from the camps and it's them who are
stopping aid agencies bringing health
care in in the past the Burmese
government would have simply acted
decisively and forced their will on the
people now they say they're powerless to
act the reclined Buddhists are one of
many Burmese minorities worried about
their place in a country emerging from
decades of military rule
at this village the fishermen tell me
that they should be receiving aid not
the reinjure who they say have come here
illegally from Bangladesh back in a
ranger camp near sittwe there's no one
with medical training but if you're
desperate and you've got money you visit
this little shack one of today's
patients is a painfully thin two month
old baby boy called mama row him he's
given rehydration fluids but his needs
are clearly much greater we suffer and
we die that is our fate his mum tells me
there are those who are calling what's
happening here a slow-burning genocide
others ethnic cleansing whatever words
you choose this is a human tragedy
people trapped in camps dying and denied
the most basic of Rights
Jonah Fisher BBC news Rakhine State
Myanmar
